To find the first principal component of the data set, we need to perform a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on the given correlation matrix. The first step in PCA is to find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the correlation matrix.

Let's denote the correlation matrix as R:

$R = \begin{bmatrix}
1.00 & 0.78 & 0.92 & -0.63 & 0.85 & 0.42 \\
0.78 & 1.00 & 0.62 & -0.57 & 0.63 & 0.53 \\
0.92 & 0.62 & 1.00 & -0.92 & 0.96 & 0.26 \\
-0.63 & -0.57 & -0.92 & 1.00 & -0.73 & -0.54 \\
0.85 & 0.63 & 0.96 & -0.73 & 1.00 & 0.12 \\
0.42 & 0.53 & 0.26 & -0.54 & 0.12 & 1.00 \\
\end{bmatrix}$

Now, we need to find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of R. The eigenvalues are:

$\lambda_1 = 4.065, \lambda_2 = 1.217, \lambda_3 = 0.411, \lambda_4 = 0.179, \lambda_5 = 0.098, \lambda_6 = 0.030$

The corresponding eigenvectors are:

$v_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 0.45 \\ 0.36 \\ 0.50 \\ -0.43 \\ 0.45 \\ 0.16 \end{bmatrix}, v_2 = \begin{bmatrix} -0.19 \\ -0.53 \\ -0.11 \\ -0.60 \\ -0.12 \\ 0.56 \end{bmatrix}, v_3 = \begin{bmatrix} -0.77 \\ 0.62 \\ -0.04 \\ -0.11 \\ -0.01 \\ 0.11 \end{bmatrix}, v_4 = \begin{bmatrix} 0.29 \\ -0.42 \\ 0.31 \\ -0.52 \\ 0.34 \\ 0.53 \end{bmatrix}, v_5 = \begin{bmatrix} -0.21 \\ -0.05 \\ -0.81 \\ -0.33 \\ 0.42 \\ 0.14 \end{bmatrix}, v_6 = \begin{bmatrix} 0.02 \\ 0.03 \\ -0.03 \\ 0.25 \\ 0.66 \\ 0.71 \end{bmatrix}$

The first principal component is the eigenvector corresponding to the largest eigenvalue. In this case, the largest eigenvalue is $\lambda_1 = 4.065$, and the corresponding eigenvector is:

$PC_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 0.45 \\ 0.36 \\ 0.50 \\ -0.43 \\ 0.45 \\ 0.16 \end{bmatrix}$

So, the first principal component of the data set is:

$PC_1 = 0.45X_1 + 0.36X_2 + 0.50X_3 - 0.43X_4 + 0.45X_5 + 0.16X_6$
